entry.title: Angular CQRS https request in nw.js
entry.content: This articl records my experience with development on â€œNW.js + Angularâ€, implementing https request by $http. pure $httpin nw.js + angualr: host = "192.168.10.69"; $http({ method : 'POST', url : "https://" + host + '/mediawise/auth', data: '{"protocols": ["5.2.6"], "user": "'+ $scope.user.name + '","password":"' + $scope.user.pwd +'"}', }) .then (function(res) { setLocalStorage("cur_user", $scope.user.name); setLocalStorage("vdnaGenPwd_" + $scope.user.name, $scope.user.pwd); if($scope.remember == true){ $scope.remPwd(); } else { setLocalStorage("pwd_" + $scope.user.name, null); } $scope.user = {name : '', pwd : ''}; $scope.remember = false; window.location = "main.html"; }, function(res) { console.log (JSON.stringigy (res.data)); }); in Nginx config: if ($request_method = 'OPTIONS') { add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' '*'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials' 'true'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' 'GET, POST, OPTIONS'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' 'DNT,X-CustomHeader,Keep-Alive,User-Agent,X-Requested-With,If-Modified-Since,Cache-Control,Content-Type'; add_header 'Access-Control-Max-Age' 1728000; add_header 'Content-Type' 'text/plain charset=UTF-8'; add_header 'Content-Length' 0; return 204; } if ($request_method = 'POST') { add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' '*'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials' 'true'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' 'GET, POST, OPTIONS'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' 'DNT,X-CustomHeader,Keep-Alive,User-Agent,X-Requested-With,If-Modified-Since,Cache-Control,Content-Type'; } if ($request_method = 'GET') { add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' '*'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials' 'true'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' 'GET, POST, OPTIONS'; add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' 'DNT,X-CustomHeader,Keep-Alive,User-Agent,X-Requested-With,If-Modified-Since,Cache-Control,Content-Type'; } if you meet this error: Basically you need to use: "chromium-args": "--allow-running-insecure-content --ignore-certificate-errors", And it has to go outside of the window object (e.g. after name property) in the package.json file. eg: 123456789101112131415161718192021{ "name": "VDNA", "chromium-args": "--enable-file-cookies --allow-running-insecure-content --ignore-certificate-errors", "main": "index.html", "descrption": "client for Ingesting, Query and manage VDNA meta", "version": "0.1.0", "dependencies": { "request": "^2.49.0" }, "window": { "title": "VDNA", "icon": "images/login_bg.png", "toolbar": true, "frame": true, "width": 1180, "height": 820, "position": "center", "min_width": 960, "min_height": 660 } } node request()12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728function do_request (method, path, data, callback){ var request = require('request'); var options = { url: 'https://192.168.10.111' + path, method: method, rejectUnauthorized: false, //very important headers: { //'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded', //'Content-Length': data.length, 'Cookie': getLocalStorage ("auth_token") }, }; if (method != 'GET' && data != null) { options.body = data; } request (options, callback); /* callback = function (error, response, body) { if (!error && response.statusCode == 200) { ... } } */} or 1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344function do_request2 (method, path, data, callback) { //process.env.NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED = "0"; var https = require('https'); var options = { host: '192.168.10.113', port: 443, path: path, method: method, rejectUnauthorized: false, headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded', 'Content-Length': data.length, 'Cookie': getLocalStorage ("auth_token") } }; var req = https.request(options, callback); req.on('error', function(e) { console.error(e); }); req.write(data); req.end(); /* //callback eg: callback = function (res) { var xxx = ""; res.on('data', function (d) { process.stdout.write('RESPONSE:' + d); xxx += d; }); res.on ('end', function () { if (res.statusCode == 200) { //handle received data:xxx } } } */} å‚è€ƒ https://github.com/nwjs/nw.js/issues/3123#issuecomment-96393512

entry.title: $watch vs ng-change
entry.content: When something changesIn the olden days, before you used MVC frameworks such as Angular, you were probably used to doing stuff like this in jQuery: 12345function showNameChanged() { // stuff...}$('input.show-name').change(showNameChanged); This achieves the simple task of performing an operation whenever the user typed something inside an input, using JS change events. In Angular, though, most people would consider this code the equivalent: 12<input type=text ng-model=show.name>$scope.$watch('show.name', showNameChanged); Now, you might think Iâ€™m being nit picky here, but Iâ€™d usually rather write it like this: 1<input type=text ng-model=show.name ng-change="showNameChanged()"> ng-change?Iâ€™m always surprised that this directive is foreign for a lot of newcomers to Angular, and that $watch seems to be the tool everyone reach for first. ng-change is a simple directive that operates much like using jQuery to register a change event listener. In my opinion, this is the â€œrealâ€ equivalent of the first code sample we saw. The differences Using ng-change would call our showNameChanged() function only on actual changes to the input by the user. Watches, as you might know, are called in other cases too: right when theyâ€™re being defined the first time and on changes made to the value not by the user, e.g. programmatically. Iâ€™m a big believer in expressing intent when writing code (you do know The 4 Rules of Simple Design, right?). If my intent is to only listen to changes by the user, and I donâ€™t expect the input to be changed programmatically, I would rather explicitly show that. Using $watch means whenever you read this code in the future youâ€™ll have to consider whether itâ€™s being triggered by something else, too. Another plus for intent for ng-change is that you can see from the template that this input is bound to something and how. Otherwise youâ€™d need to start looking for the value in ng-model in the controller for usages. This way you can see right away whoâ€™s listening for these changes. Less code. And â€œless code == less things to debugâ€. As you can see above we didnâ€™t need to add another line to the controller to listen for input changes. Using ng-change is a tiny bit more performant, since it uses one less watch expression. Since Angular knows it should only call the expression on change events it doesnâ€™t need to keep evaluating it on every digest cycle, as opposed to, well, a watch. Yes, just this one doesnâ€™t matter a lot, but across a big app these things stack up. Of course, sometimes $watch is what you want. But sometimes â€“ it ainâ€™t! References http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15112584/angularjs-using-scope-watch-and-scope-apply http://www.angularjs.cn/A0a6
